Standard Operating Procedure.Title: Reading and Interpreting Explanation of Benefits (EOB) from Other Payers

Purpose: To establish and document uniform and consistent guidelines for reading and interpreting dual coverage and Coordination of Benefits (COB) in another payer's received EOB.
Expected Outcome: Claims personnel will request an EOB from another payer if Molina is the secondary or tertiary payer and will use the guidelines in this SOP to read and interpret the other payer's payment information.

Definitions.Definition: Health insurance provision under which the insurer (for example, Molina) and the insured (member) share costs incurred after the deductible is met, according to a specific formula (80%/20% or other defined percentage).

Flat fee the member or responsible party pays for certain plan benefits. This is a cost-sharing arrangement whereby the member is financially responsible for a specified amount of the care. The co-payment is generally due and payable to the provider at the time the member receives the care and, typically, is a predetermined fee.
The total amount of money the member/patient must pay during the calendar year for certain plan benefits before the payer begins to pay.

A document (sometimes referred to as EOMB for Explanation of Medical Benefits) that is usually computer/system-generated and explains, for example:
• How benefits were calculated and disbursed,
• Any applied deductible amounts,
• Applicable co-pay the member owes, and
• Amounts not covered.

The plan/carrier/payer whose plan pays first, based on the standard industry guidelines for group/commercial/ employer-sponsored plans or Medicare Secondary Payer (MSP) guidelines for senior plans/Medicare.

The plan/carrier/payer whose plan pays second, based on the standard industry guidelines for group/commercial/ employer-sponsored plans or Medicare Secondary Payer (MSP) guidelines for senior plans/Medicare.

The plan/carrier/payer whose plan pays third, based on the standard industry guidelines for group/commercial/ employer-sponsored plans or Medicare Secondary Payer (MSP) guidelines for senior plans/Medicare.

Same as "prevailing fee" and "Reasonable & Customary" (R&C). This is the fee regularly charged and received by the healthcare provider for a given service that does not exceed the general level of charges as determined by Medicare/CMS, Medicaid state regulatory agency, or other payer. It is made by providers of similar training and experience after furnishing customary treatment for similar sickness, condition, or injury. The locality where the charge is incurred is also considered, based on ZIP code or a geographically-defined region.

General Information.Description: Other payers’ EOBs are formatted in a variety of different ways but, essentially, contain the same information. The usual information found on an EOB (detailed explanation of payment or remittance advice) is summarized below:

Data Elements.Explanation: Date EOB was generated or printed.
Organization, group, or entity that processed the claim.
Name, address, and phone number of the claim office (sometimes service hours are also listed).
Name of insured individual or member, plus member’s identification number.
If the claim is for a dependent, the name of the dependent.
Group number, employer identification number, or group name.

Claim number, DCN (document control number), or TCN (transaction control number), which is usually computer/system assigned. These numbers are used by the claim payer to identify the claim, and some EOBs may contain both a claim number and a DCN.

Provider Name.Details: Provider's name will be shown along with, typically, all or part of the provider's address.

Provider ID.Details: ID Number, TIN, NPI assigned to the healthcare provider.

Charges.Details: Identified as the charge, billed amount, or billed charge(s). This is the full amount billed by the provider (provider's usual fee for service) before any plan provisions or limitations are applied during the adjudication process.

Date of Service.Details: Service date(s) in a single space or two spaces with dates designated 'Service Date From' and 'Service Date To.' These are the inclusive dates of service.

Amount Disallowed.Details: This column or area may go by a variety of terms: Network Savings, Amount Not Covered, Provider Savings, Amount Not Allowed, Amount Disallowed, PPO Reduction, or Discounted Amount. This represents the amount 'saved' by the payer contracting with the provider and represents a patient discount or savings. The patient is not responsible for paying the provider this amount. This space/column may also include any amount that exceeds U&C (or R&C) for plans that use U&C as a limiting dollar amount. These amounts are significant because the billed charges minus the amounts disallowed equal the other payer's allowable—a key figure/amount used in the COB calculation.

Other Insurance.Details: Shows amount another insurance paid if the payer is secondary. Usually, this will be blank or show as zero, since Molina will be secondary in most cases in which Molina requests an EOB; however, in some cases, Molina may be a tertiary payer (that is, Molina pays third).

Amount Paid.Details: A amount actually paid to the provider after disallowances, plan provisions, and application of provider contract rate(s).

DataElement.Name: Patient Responsibility
DataElement.Details: Also may show as "Amount You Owe Provider" or "It is your responsibility to pay." This is the amount the patient must pay after the insurance pays (in the absence of a secondary payer), including co-insurance and deductibles. Also includes any non-covered items that the patient is responsible for that are not a plan benefit.

DataElement.Name: Deductible, Co-insurance, or Co-pay Amounts
DataElement.Details: If any deductible or co-insurance is applicable, it is usually clearly marked in a field or column. The EOB may also indicate the amount of deductible remaining to be met.

IncludesInformationSuchAs: Deductible amount taken so far this year
Various internal maximums (such as mental health benefits paid current year-to-date, chiropractic benefits paid current year-to-date, physical therapy benefits paid current year-to-date, and so on)

title: Instructions Regarding Appeal Procedure, continued

sections.content: These are explanations, notes, remarks, or detailed messages (like Molina’s remit remarks) that explain the claim handling, such as:
bullet_points: This procedure is considered incidental when billed with related primary procedures and additional charges are not payable. The member is not responsible for this amount.
This is the amount in excess of the allowed expense for a participating provider; therefore, the member is not responsible for this amount.

By using a network provider, you have helped to control healthcare costs and maximize your benefits. If you have used a provider that is not part of the plan network, you are responsible for the provider discount.
Co-pays do not apply to your deductible.
This balance is the member's coinsurance responsibility.

sections.content: This is an explanation of the appeal procedure or provider dispute resolution mechanism. In some cases this information appears on the back of the EOB. The requirements to file a typical notice of appeal, generally, includes:
bullet_points: Format of the appeal (it must usually be in writing);

description: This is an explanation of the appeal procedure or provider dispute resolution mechanism. In some cases this information appears on the back of the EOB. The requirements to file a typical notice of appeal, generally, includes:
requirements: Format of the appeal (it must usually be in writing);
Appeal must include the reasons why the member believes the claim decision was incorrect;
Where and to whose attention the appeal should be sent;
Time frame for filing (for example, within 120 or 180 days of receipt of EOB);
Time frame for the payer to respond with a decision after receiving the appeal (for example, within 30 days);
Rights of the member or the member's authorized representative (for example, right to request copies of all documents relevant to the appeal);
Whether the member has additional rights if the original claim decision is upheld, including the option of a second appeal, arbitration, court hearing, and such;
If a second appeal is allowed, the time frame for filing a second appeal;
Payer's time frame to respond to a second appeal.
note: The exact wording of an appeal varies by payer, type of coverage, line of business, and state.

EOB_Key_Information.EOB_Key_Information: Date here is used to determine timely filing.
This date stamp is the MHI received date.
Allowed amount(s) are under the ALLOWED AMOUNT column.

If applicable, patient responsibility is identified with letters under the PATIENT LIABILITY column to identify liability type. Patient is held liable for the co-pay when the letter 'P' is next to the dollar amount.
Paid amount can be found under the PAYABLE AMOUNT column.

Reason_Code_Legend.Code_45: Charges exceed your contracted/legislated fee arrangement.

Explanation_of_Benefits.Message_Description: PAID ACCORDING TO NETWORK: FIRST CHOICE (EBMC) BILLED CHARGES HAVE BEEN ADJUSTED TO THE CONTRACTUAL AMOUNT. THE PATIENT IS NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE BILLED CHARGES AND THE ALLOWABLE CHARGES. COPAY-COINSURANCE APPLIED

Field_or_Data.EOB_Key_Information: A code for descriptions that explain reasons for allowances, disallowances, and handling of specific line items
A code that is assigned for reference for allowances, disallowances, and handling of specific line items.
A full description of the reason codes present on the EOB.

Revision Summary.Comments: Updated document to current formatting standards
